newsitem.title: FINLAND: Analysts firm on Nokia after Ericsson Q3.
newsitem.headline: Analysts firm on Nokia after Ericsson Q3.

text.p: Analysts on Tuesday said they would stand behind their views of telecom group Nokia's outlook after its Swedish rival Ericsson reported nine-month results squarely in line with predictions.
Ericsson's report did not change their assessments on Nokia, which is due to release January-September results on November 14. Analysts were, however, still working on their forecasts.
"The result was entirely as expected and won't change my outlook for Nokia at all," said Jyrki Hilli of Arctos Securities.
"I don't think anybody will be making very big adjustments in their Nokia forecasts on the basis of this," he added.

The trend in Ericsson's net sales, rising to 78. 20 billion crowns in the nine months to end-September from 66.90 billion in the year-ago period, boded well for Nokia's earnings prospects, Hilli said.

That view was backed by Protos Securities analyst Jari Vayrynen: "The third quarter was even a shade better than expected ... It shows that the underlying business is doing well," he said. "There was no bad news."
Ericsson said it was strengthening its position as a leading supplier of digital mobile phones, but analysts did not expect this to be at the expense of Nokia's market share.
"It is Motorola Inc who is losing and will continue to lose for some quarters," said one analyst who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"Nokia will at least hold its (market) share," he said.
Though Ericsson's result brought no surprises, Ericsson and Nokia fell after the report as investors took profits from steady gains since end-July.
Nokia earlier fell to a session low of 207.00 markka, down four percent from Monday's 215.50 close, but firmed to 213.00 markka in late afternoon trade.
General softness on the bourse also dragged the share.

"The whole environment has been soft today," Hilli said, adding that Ericsson had been expected to weigh in with good news and so the in-line result did not boost the market as it could have if expectations had been dimmer.
"Ericsson has risen 13 percent in a month, Nokia has gained 6-7 percent, and Motorola has fallen 8 percent," Vayrynen said.
"It seems obvious that some people thought it was now time to take a few profits."
